5392.05.text:
to J.E., at the post-office there; you can
go and inquire in about a week

5396.22.text:
after you send your letter, if any are come,
and act accordingly."

5400.82.text:
This scheme I went over twice, thrice; it
was then digested in my mind; I

5406.66.text:
had it in a clear practical form: I felt satisfied,

5413.13.text:
With earliest day, I was up: I had my advertisement
written, enclosed,

5417.80.text:
and directed before the bell rang to rouse

5422.70.text:
"A young lady accustomed to tuition" (had
I not been a teacher two

5428.08.text:
years?) "is desirous of meeting with a situation
in a private family

5431.20.text:
where the children are under fourteen (I thought

5435.13.text:
eighteen, it would not do to undertake the

5438.92.text:
own age). She is qualified to teach the usual

5443.34.text:
education, together with French, Drawing,

5448.37.text:
reader, this now narrow catalogue of accomplishments,

5452.32.text:
held tolerably comprehensive). "Address, J.E.,
Post-office, Lowton, —-

5461.95.text:
This document remained locked in my drawer

5466.28.text:
leave of the new superintendent to go to Lowton,
in order to perform some

5469.88.text:
small commissions for myself and one or two

5472.86.text:
permission was readily granted; I went. It
was a walk of two miles, and

5478.37.text:
the evening was wet, but the days were still

5482.57.text:
two, slipped the letter into the post-office,

5486.88.text:
rain, with streaming garments, but with a

5491.03.text:
The succeeding week seemed long: it came to
an end at last, however, like

5495.73.text:
all sublunary things, and once more, towards

5499.68.text:
autumn day, I found myself afoot on the road

5504.50.text:
track it was, by the way; lying along the

5508.45.text:
the sweetest curves of the dale: but that

5513.26.text:
letters, that might or might not be awaiting

5516.76.text:
whither I was bound, than of the charms of

5521.29.text:
My ostensible errand on this occasion was

5525.20.text:
shoes; so I discharged that business first,
and when it was done, I

5529.05.text:
stepped across the clean and quiet little

5532.08.text:
the post-office: it was kept by an old dame,

5537.49.text: her nose, and black mittens on her hands.

5540.53.text: "Are there any letters for J.E.?" I asked.

5544.97.text:
She peered at me over her spectacles, and
then she opened a drawer and

5548.33.text:
fumbled among its contents for a long time,

5552.95.text:
to falter. At last, having held a document
before her glasses for nearly

5556.87.text:
five minutes, she presented it across the

5561.01.text:
by another inquisitive and mistrustful glance—it
was for J.E.

5569.95.text:
"There are no more," said she; and I put it

5575.87.text:
face homeward: I could not open it then; rules

5580.46.text: eight, and it was already half-past seven.

5583.70.text:
Various duties awaited me on my arrival. I

5587.99.text:
during their hour of study; then it was my

5591.97.text:
them to bed: afterwards I supped with the

5596.06.text:

5599.93.text:
companion: we had only a short end of candle

5604.18.text:
dreaded lest she should talk till it was all

5607.77.text:
however, the heavy supper she had eaten produced

5611.60.text:
was already snoring before I had finished

5615.44.text:
remained an inch of candle: I now took out

5619.91.text:
initial F.; I broke it; the contents were

5624.47.text:
"If J.E., who advertised in the _—-shire

5628.93.text:
possesses the acquirements mentioned, and

5632.83.text:
satisfactory references as to character and

5637.23.text:
be offered her where there is but one pupil,

5640.80.text:
years of age; and where the salary is thirty
pounds per annum. J.E. is

5645.56.text:
requested to send references, name, address,
and all particulars to the

5654.74.text:
I examined the document long: the writing

5661.55.text:
uncertain, like that of an elderly lady. This

5666.61.text:
satisfactory: a private fear had haunted me,

5670.58.text:
myself, and by my own guidance, I ran the
risk of getting into some

5674.40.text:
scrape; and, above all things, I wished the

5679.53.text:
respectable, proper, _en regle_. I now felt

5683.55.text:
bad ingredient in the business I had on hand.
Mrs. Fairfax! I saw her

5689.01.text:
in a black gown and widow's cap; frigid, perhaps,
but not uncivil: a

5693.33.text:
model of elderly English respectability. Thornfield!
that, doubtless,

5695.69.text:
was the name of her house: a neat orderly
spot, I was sure; though I

5703.74.text:
failed in my efforts to conceive a correct
plan of the premises.

5707.30.text:
Millcote, —-shire; I brushed up my recollections
of the map of England,

5712.58.text:
yes, I saw it; both the shire and the town.
—-shire was seventy miles

5717.62.text:
nearer London than the remote county where
I now resided: that was a

5721.28.text:
recommendation to me. I longed to go where
there was life and movement:

5725.69.text:
Millcote was a large manufacturing town on
the banks of the A-; a busy

5730.72.text:
place enough, doubtless: so much the better;
it would be a complete

5734.96.text:
change at least. Not that my fancy was much
captivated by the idea of

5739.79.text:
long chimneys and clouds of smoke—"but,"
I argued, "Thornfield will,

5744.87.text: probably, be a good way from the town."

5748.48.text:
Here the socket of the candle dropped, and
the wick went out.

5753.50.text:
Next day new steps were to be taken; my plans
could no longer be confined

5757.83.text:
to my own breast; I must impart them in order
to achieve their success.

5762.88.text:
Having sought and obtained an audience of
the superintendent during the

5766.01.text:
noontide recreation, I told her I had a prospect

5769.74.text:
situation where the salary would be double

5773.80.text:
Lowood I only got 15 pounds per annum); and

5777.96.text:
matter for me to Mr. Brocklehurst, or some

5781.66.text:
ascertain whether they would permit me to

5785.42.text:
obligingly consented to act as mediatrix in

5789.95.text:

5793.83.text:
written to, as she was my natural guardian.
A note was accordingly

5798.19.text:

5802.82.text:
pleased: she had long relinquished all interference

5807.06.text:

at last, after what appeared to

5810.67.text:
me most tedious delay, formal leave was given

5814.90.text:
if I could; and an assurance added, that as
I had always conducted myself

5819.51.text:
well, both as teacher and pupil, at Lowood,

5824.09.text:
and capacity, signed by the inspectors of

5830.76.text:
This testimonial I accordingly received in

5834.30.text:

5838.62.text:
was satisfied, and fixing that day fortnight

5842.73.text: assuming the post of governess in her house.

5845.63.text:
I now busied myself in preparations: the fortnight
passed rapidly. I had

5850.86.text:
not a very large wardrobe, though it was adequate

5854.63.text:
last day sufficed to pack my trunk,—the
same I had brought with me eight

5861.64.text:
The box was corded, the card nailed on. In

5866.21.text:
to call for it to take it to Lowton, whither

5870.37.text:
early hour the next morning to meet the coach.
I had brushed my black

5873.80.text:
stuff travelling-dress, prepared my bonnet,

5878.35.text:

5882.47.text:

5887.45.text:
had been on foot all day, I could not now

5891.47.text:
much excited. A phase of my life was closing

5897.53.text:
to-morrow: impossible to slumber in the interval;
I must watch feverishly

5902.17.text: while the change was being accomplished.

5904.92.text:
"Miss," said a servant who met me in the lobby,

5909.14.text:
like a troubled spirit, "a person below wishes

5913.33.text:
"The carrier, no doubt," I thought, and ran

5918.93.text:
was passing the back-parlour or teachers'

5922.20.text:
was half open, to go to the kitchen, when

5925.86.text:
"It's her, I am sure!—I could have told

5930.16.text:
individual who stopped my progress and took

5932.97.text:
I looked: I saw a woman attired like a well-dressed

5938.59.text:
yet still young; very good-looking, with black

5944.13.text:
"Well, who is it?" she asked, in a voice and

5948.85.text:

5953.17.text:
In another second I was embracing and kissing

5957.91.text:
Bessie! Bessie!" that was all I said; whereat

5963.53.text:
cried, and we both went into the parlour.
By the fire stood a little

5967.42.text:
fellow of three years old, in plaid frock

5970.79.text: "That is my little boy," said Bessie directly.

5978.42.text:
"Yes; nearly five years since to Robert Leaven,

5982.28.text:
little girl besides Bobby there, that I've

5988.90.text: "I live at the lodge: the old porter has left."

5992.60.text:
"Well, and how do they all get on? Tell me

5996.79.text:
Bessie: but sit down first; and, Bobby, come

6001.30.text:
you?" but Bobby preferred sidling over to

6005.21.text:
"You're not grown so very tall, Miss Jane,

6013.60.text:
Reed is the head and shoulders taller than

6017.55.text: would make two of you in breadth."

6023.47.text:
"Very. She went up to London last winter with

6027.34.text:
everybody admired her, and a young lord fell

6030.27.text:
relations were against the match; and—what

6034.40.text:
Georgiana made it up to run away; but they

6038.31.text:
was Miss Reed that found them out: I believe

6042.32.text:
and her sister lead a cat and dog life together;
they are always

6050.24.text:
"Oh, he is not doing so well as his mama could

and he got—plucked, I think they call it:

to be a barrister, and study the law: but

6062.49.text: man, they will never make much of him, I think."

6065.93.text:
"He is very tall: some people call him a fine-looking

6074.91.text:
"Missis looks stout and well enough in the

6078.44.text:
quite easy in her mind: Mr. John's conduct

6087.64.text:
"No, indeed: but I have long wanted to see

6092.39.text:
there had been a letter from you, and that

6094.65.text:
of the country, I thought I'd just set off,

6097.97.text: you were quite out of my reach."

6099.34.text:

I perceived that Bessie's glance, though it

6116.93.text:

people wish to please, and the conviction

6135.38.text:

6139.41.text:
"I dare say you are clever, though," continued

6146.00.text: "What can you do? Can you play on the piano?"

6149.50.text:
There was one in the room; Bessie went and

6153.96.text:
to sit down and give her a tune: I played

6158.76.text:
"The Miss Reeds could not play as well!" said

6168.33.text:
"That is one of my paintings over the chimney-piece."

6172.41.text:
in water colours, of which I had made a present

6176.51.text:

6181.63.text:
"Well, that is beautiful, Miss Jane! It is

6187.32.text:
Reed's drawing-master could paint, let alone

who could not come near it: and have you learnt

6194.78.text:
"Yes, Bessie, I can both read it and speak

6197.87.text: "And you can work on muslin and canvas?"

6201.94.text:
"Oh, you are quite a lady, Miss Jane! I knew

6207.41.text:

There was something I

"Well, you know Missis always said they were

6224.27.text:

are; for one day, nearly seven years ago,
